headline: Owls Complete the 2025 American Championship
content: CONCORD, N.C. - Florida Atlantic's men's and women's cross country teams competed in the American Conference Championship on Saturday morning. The Owls competed in weather they are not typically used to. They raced in a colder climate than the weather in sunny Florida. The men started with an 8K to start the morning in Concord. In their third appearance at the American Championships, the men totaled 360 points on the day, finishing 12th. On the women's side, the Owls finished ninth overall with 267 points. On the women's side Rosa ten Berg, Elyssa Toal, Madison Brown, Anabell Reumann, Leah Helms, Sophie Dethier, Reese Anderson, and Morgan Pennington competed for Florida Atlantic. ten Berg came in first for the Owls. On the men's side, Paul Glick, Donovan Petty, Samuel Henery, Nazayer Franco, Noah Highsmith, and Nathan Webb represented FAU. QUICK HITS Women ten Berg finished with a time of 22:08.1 as the top Owl finisher for the second consecutive meet. Toal came in second for the Owls as she placed 53rd overall on the course with a time of 22:17.6 Seconds behind was Brown, running a 22:28.4. Finishing 64th overall, Reumann registered a 22:42.1 Helms finished 68th overall (22:52.4) Dethier (22:59.0) and Anderson (23:45.7) finished 70th and 81st overall in their first postseason run with the Owls Men As a team, Florida Atlantic recorded 360 points on the day Glick got it started for the Owls when he was the first to cross the finish line. Right behind was the freshman Petty with a time of 26:36.8. He recorded a career-best at the American Championships, last year running a 27:00.0. Back-to-back were Franco and Highsmith in their first appearance in an American Championship Webb placed 90th overall in his first postseason appearance. UP NEXT The Owls will conclude their cross country season with the NCAA South Regionals on Friday, Nov. 14, in Huntsville, Alabama, at John Hunt Park. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage of FAU cross country and track & field, follow us on social media @FAUXCTF

headline: Owls Take Second at Mercer Invitational
content: FORSYTH, Ga. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic women's golf (+44) finished second at Monday's Mercer Invitational. The tournament hosts, Mercer, won the team title at +19. This was the final event of the fall for the Owls.Quick HitsThe Owls were led individually by Nancy Cox (+8) in fifth place.Cox finished five behind Mercer's Katie Scheck and added another Top 15 finish after a T14 and a T3 in her previous two starts this fall.Tina Genoulaz and Charlotte Perkins each tied for seventh.Giulia Scarcello finished 25th while Maddie Rathjen was 37th.What's NextThe Owls return to tournament action in February when they host the Paradise Invitational sponsored by CIEE Golf is Global.Owls on Social MediaFor complete coverage of FAU women's golf, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUWGolf).

headline: Florida Atlantic Sweeps Tulsa
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic volleyball team bounced back in a big way on Sunday, earning a straight-set sweep over the Tulsa Golden Hurricane, 3-0 (25-23, 25-18, 25-17) on Sunday afternoon inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. HOW IT HAPPENED Tulsa took an early 8-5 lead to open the match, forcing an early FAU timeout. Following a 14-10 Tulsa advantage, Anna Hartman scored three-straight kills for FAU, battling the Owls back within one at 14-13. Back-to-back Golden Hurricane errors evened the match at 15 apiece. Following a 21-19 Tulsa advantage, the Owls went on a 5-1 run to force a pair of Golden Hurricane timeouts, holding set point at 24-22. Tulsa got one back, but a service error closed out the first set, giving the Owls the 25-23 win. Tulsa opened the second set with a 13-9 lead, forcing an early Owl timeout. Trailing by four at 17-13, the Owls locked in and dominated the remainder of the set. Five straight Tulsa errors sparked a 12-1 FAU run to close the second set as the Owls claimed the 25-18 win to take a two-set advantage, 2-0. After battling through a 7-7 tie to open the third, the Owls produced a 7-1 run to take a six-point lead and force nearly back-to-back timeouts from the Golden Hurricane, leading 14-8. The Owls extended their lead to nine, following a pair of kills from Libby Ashline and a pair of Tulsa errors, 22-13. The Golden Hurricane cut the deficit to six, 23-17, but another Golden Hurricane error and a kill from Hartman clinched the straight-set sweep for the Owls, 25-17. STATS & NOTES Hartman led the way for the Owls, recording a match-leading 12 kills, hitting an impressive .571, while Kierstin Bevelle, Kayla Richardson, and Ashline followed just behind, tying for second on the team with eight kills each. Emsley Venard dished out a team-best 22 assists against the Golden Hurricane. Defensively, Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, tying for a match-best 12 digs, while Libby Ashline led the Owls at the net, posting a team-best six blocks in the win. As a team, the Owls dominated the Golden Hurricane on the block, 10 to four, in addition to holding advantages in kills (46), hitting percentage (.346), assists (43), and digs (43). The win ties the all-time series between Florida Atlantic and Tulsa, 2-2. UP NEXT The Owls will head out on their final regular-season road trip next weekend as they visit Tulane on Friday, Nov. 7, before facing Rice in their road finale on Sunday, Nov. 9. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Tie Tulsa, Earn Share of Conference Regular Season Title
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer (10-3-2, 5-1-2) tied Tulsa (4-8-4, 3-3-2) 0-0 on Sunday. With Charlotte tying Missouri State, the Owls and the 49ers share the title of Regular Season Champions of the American Conference. It's the third regular season conference title in program history and the first since 2007. Florida Atlantic entered the night needing to match Charlotte's result against Missouri State or better it to become the outright champions. The Owls launched 19 shot attempts at the Tulsa goal but could not find a breakthrough. On the other end, goalkeeper Guilherme Pipolo made three saves to record his first solo clean sheet. The Owls will be the number two seed and receive a first-round bye in the American Conference Tournament. They will meet the winner of USF and Tulsa in the semifinals on Wednesday, November 12, at 3:30 p.m. The semis and the championship will both be hosted in Charlotte, North Carolina. To view the full bracket, visit https://theamerican.org/news/2025/11/3/field-set-for-2025-american-conference-mens-soccer-championship.aspx. Head coach Joey Worthen Postgame with @joeyworthen #WIPüèùÔ∏è pic.twitter.com/t2H1fYdef3 ‚Äî Florida Atlantic Men's Soccer (@FAUMSoccer) November 3, 2025 FOLLOW US For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Open Season With Overtime Victory Over Boston College
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Late game heroics from freshman Yohann Sissoko lifted the Florida Atlantic men's basketball team past Boston College in an 83-78 overtime win at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Monday night. The Owls (1-0) battled back from a late second half deficit versus the Eagles (0-1) to tie the game and missed just one shot in the extra five minutes to start the season with a victory, their first over a power conference team at home since December of 2002 against Miami. FIRST HALF A nearly full court pass to a wide-open redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool for the slam dunk opened the Owls' scoring. A 12-3 Owls run, highlighted by nine points from junior Xander Pintelon, gave FAU a nine-point lead. A three-pointer by redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams put Florida Atlantic up by 10 for the first time of the night. Boston College closed the deficit to one, but junior guard Kanaan Carlyle hit a late three-pointer to give the Owls a 35-31 advantage entering halftime. SECOND HALF Six straight points from Isaiah Elohim built Florida Atlantic's lead, with the redshirt sophomore guard putting together a highlight reel sequence of plays featuring a driving slam dunk followed by an acrobatic and-one. The Eagles tied the game with 10 minutes remaining and soon took a six-point lead off the 8-0 run. Boston College was up by nine with under five minutes left, but the lead was cut to three in less than a minute with back-to-back three pointers from Sissoko and Carlyle. Down by five with 46 seconds to play, the Owls forced a turnover to get the ball back, with Carlyle drawing the foul and sinking two free throws to cut the score to 66-63. The Eagles did not have an opportunity to close out the game, with Sissoko intercepting a pass and drilling a shot from beyond the arc to tie the score at 66 apiece with 31 seconds on the clock. Neither team scored again, sending the game into overtime. OVERTIME The duo of Carlyle and Sissoko came up clutch once again, with the former sinking a three to tie it at 78-78 and a driving layup from Sissoko to take a lead that the Owls did not relinquish. A three-pointer from Pintelon with just over a minute to go put Florida Atlantic up by six, sealing the victory. PRESS CONFERENCES GALLERY Gallery: (11-3-2025) MBB vs. Boston College STATS & NOTES The Owls last played an overtime game at the Elly in February of 2023, also an FAU victory. Among the five players with double digit scoring, Carlyle finished with 19 points to lead the team. Vanterpool nabbed a career high nine rebounds, eight coming in the first half. He also dished out a career best six assists to lead the Owls. Sissoko finished with 15 points in his collegiate debut, finishing a perfect three-for-three from beyond the arc. As a team, the Owls shot 52% (12-for-23) from three-point range. Pintelon recorded four blocks. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will travel to Lynchburg, Virginia, for the third edition of the Field of 68 Classic on Saturday, Nov. 8, against Charleston and Sunday, Nov. 9, versus host Liberty. Both games tip off at 6 p.m. on YouTube. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Owls Open Season Tuesday vs. Florida Memorial
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic women's basketball will tip off the 2025-26 season on Tuesday, hosting the Florida Memorial Lions for a 7 p.m. tip off inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on ESPN+. The Owls' season opener is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union. Fans in attendance will receive a free rally towel. A LOOK AT THE OWLS Florida Atlantic enters its inaugural season under Head Coach LeAnn Freeland. Freeland brings a winning culture to Boca Raton, boasting a 363-159 career record over her 17 seasons as a head coach, including six conference championships, 11 NCAA Tournament appearances, four Elite Eight appearances, and one Final Four appearance. The Owls' return Ta'Ziah Jenks, Erin Rodgers, and Zahira Arizmendi from last year's squad. Rodgers highlights the Owls' returners, who led the team last season in rebounding per contest, averaging 5.6 rebounds per game, and finished second on the team in scoring average, recording 12 points per game during the 2024-25 campaign. Jenks ranked third on the team last season in rebounding, averaging 5.3 rebounds per game. She is also the Owls' returning leader in steals and assists, averaging 1.2 steals and 1.0 assists per game last season. The Owls also welcome eight newcomers, including Destyne Jackson, Grace Carstensen, Jess Moors, Michiyah Simmons, Ineivi Plata, Haley Walker, Madi Gewirtz, and Vivian Onugha. SCOUTING FLORIDA MEMORIAL Florida Memorial enters Tuesday's contest at 1-0 overall after opening their season with a 74-47 win against the University of Fort Lauderdale. Last season, the Lions finished with a 24-5 overall record and a 13-3 mark in Sun Conference play. FMU earned its first-ever NAIA Tournament win, defeating Indiana Northwest 85-76 in the opening round, before concluding its season with a 68-47 loss against Freed-Hardeman in the second round. The Lions are in their second season under head coach Kevin Herod. FMU returns two from its 2024-25 squad in Alicia Bates and Kalea Rainey and welcomes nine newcomers. Rainey and Sa'mya Stevens lead the Lions, tying for a team-best 15 points in their season opener. Stevens also leads the Lions in assists, dishing out a team-best seven against Fort Lauderdale. Jazlynn Givens leads FMU in rebounding, collecting seven rebounds to open the season. Defensively, Alicia Bates is the Lions' steals leader, collecting a team-leading nine steals, and Aalexuz Bourne leads the team in blocks, recording the Lions' sole block vs. Fort Lauderdale. SERIES HISTORY Tuesday will mark the 22nd all-time meeting between Florida Atlantic and Florida Memorial. The Owls hold a 20-1 all-time lead against the Lions and have won the last 14 matchups between the two programs. In the last meeting between the two squads, the Owls captured a 71-63 win on Dec. 7, 2021, at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena in Boca Raton. SEASON PREVIEW UP NEXT Following Tuesday's contest, the Owls will open a three-game road stretch, beginning with a trip to Kennesaw, Georgia, on Saturday, Nov. 8, to face off against the Kennesaw State Owls. Tipoff is scheduled for 7 p.m. ET inside the KSU Convocation Center and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook.

headline: Zettl Earns Final Weekly Honorable Mention
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer senior Sebastian Zettl has been named as an American Conference Weekly Honorable Mention for the final week of the regular season. Zettl returned from injury on Wednesday against USF and made an immediate impact in just 24 minutes of second half action. The Austrian delivered the free kick that was redirected home by Aboubacar Traore to tie the game 3-3. With 15 seconds left in the match, he connected on a shot from outside the box that beat the keeper and gave the Owls a dramatic 4-3 victory. The Owls drew with Tulsa 0-0 on Sunday night to claim a share of the American Conference regular season title. They will face either USF or Tulsa in the semifinals on Wednesday, November 12, at 3:30 p.m. in Charlotte, N.C. FOLLOW US For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Kickoff Set for 4 p.m. in the Big Easy
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic football game on Saturday, Nov. 15 at Tulane is set for 4 p.m. ET and will air on ESPN+. FAU will travel to New Orleans to face Tulane for the first time despite the series standing at 1-1. The Owls won the first game of the series 34-17 back on November 2, 2013 and lost their last meeting, also in Boca Raton by a 24-8 score. Florida Atlantic played in New Orleans one other time, defeating Memphis in the 2007 New Orleans Bowl by a score of 44-27.

headline: Inside the Owls Burrow, S10, EP13
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic football celebrates its 25th season while FAU Athletics hits another milestone with Inside the Owls Burrow in its 10th season showcasing all things FAU Athletics. Episode 13 of Inside the Owls' Burrow's 2025 football season, solely produced and hosted by Frank Forte, will air at 3 p.m., a new time, on Thursday, Nov. 6 where it will originate each week throughout the fall on FanDuel Sports Network Florida. It will re-air Saturday, Nov. 8 at 11:30 a.m. The weekly show's 13th installment of the fall will feature Forte talking one-on-one with first-year Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley about the Owls' upcoming game versus Tulsa as the final third of the schedule gets underway following a bye week by both teams. Redshirt junior WR Jayshon Platt and his breakout season is highlighted. Platt stands among the nation's leaders in all-purpose yards as well as combined kick returns. Redshirt junior S Jayden Sweeney is the subject of this week's edition of "Pads Off" and Boca Raton native and Cornerbacks Coach Antonio Fenelus talks his return to "Paradise." Plus, 25 years of Owl football is celebrated with a look back at safety Jalen's Young's three-interception game versus Marshall in 2017. THE SHOW TRAILER

headline: Smith and Onugha Named Student-Athletes of the Month
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic Athletics has named its Prestige Windows & Doors Student-Athletes of the Month for October with Payne Smith from men's swimming and diving and Vivian Onugha, who is getting ready to lead the women's basketball team in its opening week of play, receiving the honors.‚Äã The monthly awards are presented to a male and female Florida Atlantic student-athlete to recognize their excellence in the classroom. FAU's athletic academic staff votes on the award. It is the first honors for this duo. QUOTABLE "Payne has demonstrated exceptional dedication to academic excellence while balancing the high demands of athletic competition. As a senior majoring in finance, he consistently strives for success, showing focus, determination, and a strong commitment to learning. Beyond academics, Payne also serves as a leader of the SAAC Executive Board, where he plays an active role in representing fellow student-athletes and fostering a positive and inclusive athletic community. His leadership and initiative continue to make a meaningful impact both within athletics and our community." - Caroline Lohan, FAU's Athletic Academic Advisor/Learning Specialist "Vivian started with Florida Atlantic last summer and hit the ground running by taking an impressive 15 credits, and her hard work paid off with a 3.34 GPA. She is currently taking another 15 credits and has continued with her academic excellence as she currently holds nearly all A's. Vivian has shown consistency to her dedication in the classroom and is a model student-athlete. Her hard work makes her the perfect candidate to represent this month's student athlete of the month." - Jordan Pitre, FAU's Director of Student-Athlete Development/Athletic Academic Advisor. ‚Äã STUDENT-ATHLETES OF THE MONTH August - Terez Reid, football, Maja Piotrowicz, women's swimming & diving September - Mamadou Diarra, men's soccer, Stella Rubidoux, women's soccer October ‚Äì Payne Smith, men's swimming and diving, Vivian Onugha, women's basketball

headline: Rathjen‚Äôs Ace Highlights Day One in Georgia
content: FORSYTH, Ga. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic women's golf is in third place after two rounds at the Mercer Invitational. Monday's final round gets underway with a shotgun start at 9 a.m. Quick Hits The highlight of day one came at the par three 11th hole in round two when sophomore Maddie Rathjen recorded a hole-in-one. Three Owls are inside the Top 10 entering Monday's final round. Nancy Cox is tied for 4th at +4, four shots behind Mercer's Katie Scheck. Charlotte Perkins (+7) is solo ninth while Tina Genoulaz (+8) is one further back in a tie for 10th. Giulia Scarcello is tied for 17th while Rathjen is tied for 40th. The Owls are +29 as a team, 10 behind Mercer in the team competition. Owls on Social Media For complete coverage of FAU women's golf, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUWGolf).

headline: Florida Atlantic Sweeps Tulsa
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic volleyball team bounced back in a big way on Sunday, earning a straight-set sweep over the Tulsa Golden Hurricane, 3-0 (25-23, 25-18, 25-17) on Sunday afternoon inside Eleanor R.
